author: rphair
title: Community CIP Editor: 1 year budget
description: Cardano's rapid growth relative to Ethereum has not yet evolved the same level of comprehensive support for our open (CIP) standards as Ethereum has maintained for its own open (EIP) standards.

f6_assessments.q0: The goal of this proposal is to create a community CIP editor that would be the equivalent of the EIP editor of Ethereum, as Cardano grows and needs a middleman to handle designs, processes, and information documents when communicating with developers, engineers, scientists, businesspeople, and other users, and to avoid duplications and misunderstandings within the Cardano ecosystem. I am withdrawing one star as the proposal in my opinion does not fall into The Great Migration (from Ethereum) but into either Developer Ecosystem or Dapps, Products and Integrations as it is a superstructure or second layer for CIP and therefore better integration and communication of Cardano and is not about improving or increasing the transfer of users or developers from Ethereum. The benefit for Cardano is indisputable as the proponent is already doing this work and the results are traceable on GitHub.  It is true that the time required to edit the CIP is increasing due to growth, while the teams that provided the editing remain the same number of members. The short-term goal is to ensure that editors are steadily rewarded for the work they do, and the long-term goal is to create a team of people dedicated purely to CIP editing and that meets the requirements of scaling of this proposal.  If it happens that the work that is declared in this proposal is not done, payment for it would not be done either, thus the risk of not delivering value is low. If for some reason the proposer is unable to continue editing, I believe that compensation can be done by finding someone, who will continue, because it’s paid as a regular job. Since this is not a job that can pay for itself with other buyers, additional funding from Cardano is necessary.
f6_assessments.q1: The work is scheduled to be done in weeks, specifically 8 hours per week, with one hour costing $50. The budget is for one year of work, 48 weeks to be exact, paid by the month, at $1,600 per month. The work due to the CIP will be impactful at times, which assumes a higher time burden for the proposer, meaning he will be working more than 8 hours per week. Based on experience, the work is divided into normal tasks and special tasks. Normal tasks include GitHub responses, emails, communication, and CIP document code review. Specials include moderating discussions on the Cardano forums, managing communication between Cardano and mutual funds and developers, and more. The petitioner states that he is referring to a previously approved proposal from another editor who received a similar amount, declaring only 2 hours of work per week. From the experience of the proposer described in the proposal, he spends roughly an hour a day editing CIP matters, and thus, 8 hours a week seems well justified. The proposal includes relevant sources of the proposer's work history, which can be seen on GitHub, Twitter, Cardano forums, and the proposer's own website.
f6_assessments.q2: The work will be measured against a list of meeting attendees, taking into account comments, then against metrics when the editor is directly involved in CIP pull requests and issues. Results will be posted on the Cardano forum, CIP category, on Discord, in the CIP editors meeting category, in the community chat, on GitHub. They will make monthly reports that will be publicly available on the proposer's repository not just on GitHub, among other places. Success, according to the proponent, looks like building a solid, representative team of editors where every aspect of open standards in Cardan matches someone on the team. If successful, this project is then expected to create attraction with the Ethereum community and bring them to Cardana. This aspect is, in my opinion, highly speculative as it does not depend solely on the success of this project. It is more of a wish.

f6_assessments.q0: CIP Editing is a hard job and requires special skills, understanding and experience. Charles Hoskinson recently promoted the idea that we need to have more CIP editors funded by Project Catalyst. In fact, if we speak about improvements of the Cardano protocol, who should fund this work if not the protocol itself? If supported, Cardano will have one more CIP editor.
f6_assessments.q1: Robert Phair is very experienced specialist and what’s a big plus that he already has volunteered as a CIP editor for 1 year. After reading the proposal in details, I have no doubts that Robert has great understanding of CIP process and even smaller details related to the Project Catalyst.
f6_assessments.q2: The possible outcome of this proposal - positively evolving CIP process— with a solid & growing CIP repository, surrounded by positive experience & expectations in the Cardano community - this is something which all interested Cardano community would see. Also on Github, Cardano forum and Discord the work will be visible. The budget breakdown is clear and the risk of this proposal’s failure is minimal.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal is comparing EIP (Ethereum improvements proposals) vs CIP (Cardano Improvements proposals), which serve for e.g. developers or engineers to propose standards, processes to be followed by community. In practice, imagine it as a sort of a guidelines, best practices, which can really decrease the entry barrier for newcomers. The aim of the proposal is to provide a budget for a full time editor (a person who will be documenting these processes), currently performed by the proposer. The proposer is also stating, that cardano vs eth is having approx. 10 times smaller (42 vs 458) number of proposals, which can imply a worse starting position for those who would like to start developing on Cardano. Regarding the benefits of the proposal, and to highlight some – increased adoption is expected, and also it will support decentralization. To sum it up, the proposal is aiming to reduce the entry barriers for newcomers by paying a full time editor who will be documenting the best practices, and thus, it can result in more people onboarding, which I find aligned to the challenge goal.
f6_assessments.q1: Regarding the roadmap, since we are talking about writing documents – it is not really required, and the time frame is apparent from the title – 1 year. The proposer is describing the processes related to writing CIP standards, but I do not find it relevant for the assessment. But what can be taken from this description is that the proposer is highly competent to perform the job, and it is based on the following points. 1. He is already doing it for a while, and I have checked linked CIPs which I find in required quality both by language, and format. 2. The description of processes is even increasing the proposers competence, whilst a lot of details are provided. 3. Regarding his capabilities and skills, there is a huge amount of information such as links to his memberships, authorships, relevant experience is stated and also an old-fashioned Resume, which I find very attractive. Regarding the budget, the total amount is 19 200 USD requested, by 50 USD per hour, with approx. 1 hour per day which I find reasonable (not overstated). The whole proposal is prepared in the highest standard I have ever seen, which is implying that the proposer is very serious about his plans and also it is capable of delivering a high-quality content.
f6_assessments.q2: The problem (lack of CIPs documented = worse entry barriers for newcomers) and the solution (is to actually hire another editor = the proposer) is clear, and logically designed. The proposer is stating, that to track the process itself, CIP biweekly meeting minutes can be used, because there is a transcription attached with the names, which can serve as a proof of participation. For another metrics, the features of GitHub will be used such as pull requests, merges, comments, new CIPs with authorship and the proposer also plan to post monthly reports in the dedicated github. Regarding the public channels, Discord is provided.

f6_assessments.q0: This is a proposal that is aimed at improving the efficiency of the network through open standardization of open source codes and protocols and how the Blockchain operates and, also ensuring interoperability in the Blockchain industry. Project Catalyst has actually funded similar project which got great support in this direction. The notion is that if the Blockchain software is effectively open sourced and efficiently interoperable, there is very tendency to attract an influx of developers from other Blockchain platforms especially from Ethereum community. I conclude that this proposal is perfectly aligned with the tenets of the campaign objectives.
f6_assessments.q1:
From the information provided and the technical complexity of the task at hand, the proponent has shown considerable evidence of competence and experience to deliver or to continuously provide these services in addition to notable past achievements within the Cardano ecosystem.
The budget was well articulated and, reasonable basis was used to arrive at the estimates. The risk profile was was elaborate and the needed solutions were proffered.
Am convinced that the proposal will be effectively implemented accordingly.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal has provided considerable and reasonable basis to assess the project from the monthly reports via GitHub repository, CIP Editors Activities (CIP Bi Weekly Meeting Minutes, and other participatory activities on the GitHub, Discord and other forum discussions). Am convinced that there is enough information for the community to monitor and assess the progress and the level of performance by the project.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal Community CIP editor is a proposal to continue to retain qualified CIP editors, including this Proposer who has been doing the Cardano Improvement Proposals editing as a volunteer for a long term.  This proposal is for an annual compensation for continuing to edit the CIPs for $19,200.
——————————————————————————————————————————-
Without getting too technical Ethereum has around 455-460 EIPs (Ethereum Improvement Proposals) vs around 42-45 for Cardano CIPs. These proposals are a main part of what makes and keeps Cardanao and other projects -Open Source. In very non-tech speak: Proposals are submitted for tweaks to the system, e.g. Github repository; someone needs to look at it, talk about it with colleagues, write it up, code it perhaps, kick it around, discuss some more and write it up for final consideration for a change to the system.  A lot of kicking the can, and a lot of responsibility, volunteer or paid.  My understanding is Robert Phair has been pretty much involved since the beginning and is one of the few early guys with the ability to access the Github. Very simple speakease on this - Robert does a much better job at the technical talk and has lots of data to back up his creds!
———————————————————————————————————————————
I understand competition. It on one hand is the desire to do your best and yet on the other it is the need to win. Will there be a Best Blockchain or the best Web 3 or the Best Protocol? Cardano will not be it unless she Perfect practices ( it is not practice that makes better - it is Perfect Practice that makes better). If Cardano cannot keep up with and/or increase the pace of its Open Source Improvement process it cannot and will not be the best.
——————————————————————————————————————————-
This Challenge Is somewhat simple and straightforward in its complexity- make it easy for DApps & other projects to move from Ethereum to Cardano. The key word is “easy”. Without CIPs that will not occur.  With paid, professional CIP writers like Sebastian (funded in F8) and perhaps Robert and a few others Cardano can make it easy. My Assessment of the Impact of this proposal is that it is timely, important, and I rate it a 5 ( Strongly agree it meets the objective laid out in the challenge) star.

One note - if you like details, read this proposal. It is full. My job is to predigest and Assess. One note I found very insightful was on NFTs, when assessing the question I stated before - Does this Proposal Solve the problem ( make it easy)? Prior to CIPs 25 and 27 there was not a lot of quality or volume of NFTs on the Cardano block. Community members ( early fans) recognized some issues and put in some suggestions. The CIP team members ( I think all volunteers then) wrote up these two Proposals, kicked the can, sat around the coffee table, discussing and ruminating and finally something emerged that kick started an onslaught of NFT commerce. Do I assess CIP process helps to solve the problem - yes.

I Assess the feasibility of this proposal as a five ( strongly agree that it will be successfully implemented) star.

I think the strongest part of this proposal is in the section of What does success look like?  I will paste Roberts answer for your reading :UDITABILITY] What does success for this project look like?
Answer
Retention of a effective & coordinated CIP Editor team
If this proposal, and possibly similar proposals from other current or aspiring CIP editors, proceed on Catalyst, the result should be a CIP team where every aspect of open standards in Cardano is matched with someone on the team who has the time and interest to work happily in that area.

Standards & governance model visible to Ethereum community

f6_assessments.q0:
The challenge is to increase the number of projects that migrate from Ethereum to Cardano. CIP's play a very important role in projects being able to migrate over to Cardano, and Cardano's CIPS are currently very low in number as compared with Ethereum. 

Any improvements in the Cardano standards process will lead to better Cardano adoption. It will add value to the Cardano ecosystem as various projects coming up will have more CIPs to work with.  A CIP team where every aspect of open standards in Cardano is matched with someone on the team who has the time and interest to work happily in that area would have a huge and noticeable impact.

The problem is that we are asking or inviting Ethereum based developers to come over and develop on Cardano, but the Cardano standards infrastructure is far less then that of Ethereum. For Ethereum based developers to have all the advantages they have on Ethereum, the Cardano standards infrastructure needs to be vastly improved upon, which this proposal is offering that solution.
f6_assessments.q1:
Robert Phair already has 1 year unpaid experience as a CIP Editor. The proposal lays out his qualifications, achievements, skills and abilities as well as a link to his resume. He is highly qualified to do the work required in this proposal. 

The timeline/plan setout in this proposal is different then most would be because of the nature of the work involved with CIPs. The proposer has laid out the details that we need to know and is sufficient for the proposal. 

The budget laid out is clear and based on a success F8 proposal: CIP Editor time Sebastien for 1 year past. He has laid out the hour wage and broken down to weekly pay and the budget is sufficient. I believe it is highly likely that this proposal would be implemented successfully and would be easily verifiable.
f6_assessments.q2:
The list of meeting attendees is always early in the minutes and the speaker's name is next to each transcribed comment making it very easy to audit.

Furthermore, any of the following can be used for auditability of this proposal

- comment links to GitHub discussions

- message links to Discord discussions

- thread / posting links to Cardano Forum

The proposer plans to include samples of the above metrics showing the issues he was most notably involved in that month

The information provided is sufficient to audit the progress and the success of the proposal.

solution: Robert Phair has volunteered as a CIP editor for 1 year already. Paying editors for their time will retain an experienced CIP team so Cardano can satisfy users familiar with the EIP standards process.
